intro: There are several types of retirement savigns accounts, each with their own benefits. However, you must be employed to have these accounts because only earned income can contribute towards these accounts.

list: This money is TAX DEFERRED, meaning you don’t have to pay taxes on it until you withdraw it from the account.
If you invest it, you will technically be paying taxes on a much larger amount because the money grows with the market
However, this works out well because you’re expenses are much generally less when you are retired, so you're in a lower tax bracket every year
You can contribute up to 19,500 in 2020; the limit increases every year
Another big benefit: Most employers contribute towards your 401k (3-7% of your salary as long as you also contribute at least that amount to your 401k) on top of the salary they give you
Generally not vested (not given to you) until 3 years later, so you can’t leave the job before that point and still expect the employer contribution
You can not withdraw until the age of 59.5 without paying taxes + a 10% penalty
Conclusion: Good because you’re expenses (and therefore your taxes) will probably be lower when you have retired
Definitely consider if you need money in the short term because this instantly reduces your taxes
This money is TAX FREE, meaning you pay taxes now and then you can invest it your retirement account and never pay taxes on those earnings
Generally speaking, for middle class people
You can contribute up to $6,000 in 2020
This is per person, so you can open an account in your spouse’s name even if he/she is not working
You can only withdraw your contributions after 5 years of it being in the account
Conclusion: Tax free is generally better than tax deferred because you are pay 0 taxes on what will be a larger sum of money in the future
Great for long term, not great for short term, especially if you are low on cash
You must choose between Roth and Traditional IRA each year
Tax Deferred, BUT ONLY ON THE EARNINGS from your investments
You pay taxes on your contributions now, but you pay taxes on the earnings from the investments once you retire
You can contribute up to  $6000 in 2020
If your single salary is over 124k, then you can only have a Traditional IRA, not Roth IRA
Tax Free like the Roth IRA, but you can contribute $19,500 and your employer can also contribute to this
You can have a Roth IRA alongside this, but not a 401k
There is no income limit on this type of account
Conclusion: This is the best account to maximize contributions in once you have a stable living because the long-term payoff is huge.
These are guaranteed insurance contracts
Similar to Traditional IRA, in that you pay taxes on your contributions now, but your earnings are tax deferred
There is no contribution limit
Annuities have a bad rep because they are super complex and charge many expenses for keeping your money
They only invest in mutual funds, not other types of investments
The alternative is to pay lower expenses through passive mutual funds or ETFs
In annuities, you pay a premium to get tax deferral on your earnings
The best use case for annuities is when you’re retired and you want guaranteed income
Immediate Annuity - starts at age 60, you give the insurance company 100k, and they will give you 4900 every year for the rest of your life. Worth it if you live past age 80.
